title: Wire Down - Don't Touch Rule
pcr_text: Dispatch reports fallen power line across roadway. Vehicle struck power pole, driver trapped. Should you approach the scene or wait for utilities?
correct_error: Live downed power line. DO NOT APPROACH - wait for utility company per safety protocols.

options.text: Retreat and establish safe zone - wait for utility crew to de-energize
Approach using rubber gloves for protection
options.feedback: CRITICAL ERROR! Live wires require utility intervention. DO NOT TOUCH!

options.text: Begin patient assessment from distance

title: Chemical Spill - HazMat Response
pcr_text: Industrial facility with strong chemical odor, workers fleeing scene, visible vapor cloud. Should you enter or wait for HazMat team?
correct_error: Unknown chemical spill with vapor cloud. Retreat and wait for HazMat specialists per safety protocols.

options.text: Retreat to safe distance and wait for HazMat team
Enter wearing standard PPE to assess victims
options.feedback: CRITICAL ERROR! Unknown chemicals require HazMat specialists. DO NOT ENTER!

options.text: Approach upwind to avoid vapors

title: Hypothermia Stage I - Mild
pcr_text: 45-year-old found shivering outdoors in 25°F weather, alert but cold, skin cool and pale. What stage of hypothermia?
correct_error: Stage I hypothermia (mild): 90-95°F, shivering present, mental status normal per environmental protocols.

options.text: Stage I (mild) - shivering, alert, core temp 90-95°F
Stage II (moderate) - shivering stops, confusion begins
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Patient is shivering and alert - this is Stage I hypothermia.

options.text: Stage III (severe) - unconscious, core temp <86°F

hazards.action: Handle gently, prevent further heat loss

title: PPE for Suspected Tuberculosis
pcr_text: Patient with chronic cough, night sweats, weight loss. Suspected active tuberculosis. What is the most important PPE to use?
correct_error: TB PPE requirements: N95 mask mandatory for airborne protection per infection control protocols.

options.text: N95 respirator mask - required for airborne TB protection
Surgical mask - insufficient for TB protection
options.feedback: INSUFFICIENT! TB requires N95 minimum for airborne protection.

options.text: Face shield only - misses respiratory protection

title: Heat Stroke vs Heat Exhaustion
pcr_text: 60-year-old construction worker, core temp 104°F, hot dry skin, altered mental status, no sweating. Heat stroke or exhaustion?
correct_error: Heat stroke: >104°F, altered mental status, hot dry skin, no sweating per environmental protocols.

options.text: Heat stroke - immediate cooling required, altered mental status
Heat exhaustion - rest and oral fluids sufficient
options.feedback: CRITICAL ERROR! Altered mental status and hot dry skin = heat stroke, not exhaustion.

options.text: Heat cramps - electrolyte imbalance

title: Natural Gas Leak - Don't Touch
pcr_text: Apartment building with strong gas odor, hissing sound from broken pipe, residents evacuated. Should you enter or wait for gas company?
correct_error: Natural gas leak with audible hissing. DO NOT ENTER - wait for utility specialists per safety protocols.

options.text: Retreat and wait for gas company to shut off supply
Enter wearing SCBA to search for victims
options.feedback: CRITICAL ERROR! Gas leaks require utility intervention. DO NOT ENTER!

options.text: Ventilate the building from outside

title: Hypothermia Stage II - Moderate
pcr_text: 35-year-old hiker found confused and shivering violently, core temp 88°F, slow speech. What stage of hypothermia?
correct_error: Stage II hypothermia (moderate): 86-90°F, confusion, violent shivering, decreased coordination per environmental protocols.

options.text: Stage II (moderate) - confusion, violent shivering, 86-90°F
Stage I (mild) - still shivering normally
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Confusion and violent shivering indicate Stage II.

options.text: Stage III (severe) - unconscious

title: Drowning - Saltwater Near-Drowning
pcr_text: 25-year-old pulled from ocean, unconscious, frothy sputum, crackles in lungs. Saltwater or freshwater drowning?
correct_error: Saltwater drowning: pulmonary edema from hypertonic fluid shift per drowning protocols.

options.text: Saltwater drowning - fluid shifts cause pulmonary edema
Freshwater drowning - fluid enters bloodstream
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Ocean water is hypertonic - causes fluid to shift INTO lungs.

options.text: Dry drowning - laryngospasm prevents water entry

hazards.action: Support ventilation, monitor for secondary drowning

title: PPE for Bloodborne Pathogens
pcr_text: Motor vehicle crash with major bleeding, unknown patient history. What is the minimum PPE required for blood exposure?
correct_error: Bloodborne pathogen PPE: gloves mandatory, other items based on exposure risk per infection control protocols.

options.text: Non-sterile examination gloves - mandatory for blood contact
Face shield only - misses hand protection
options.feedback: INSUFFICIENT! Gloves are mandatory for blood exposure.

options.text: N95 respirator - not required for routine blood exposure

title: Carbon Monoxide Poisoning - Scene Size-up
pcr_text: House fire extinguished, family complaining of headaches, nausea, cherry-red skin. Suspected CO poisoning. Should you enter or wait?
correct_error: Carbon monoxide in enclosed space. Use CO monitor, enter with SCBA if needed per safety protocols.

options.text: Monitor CO levels, enter with SCBA if >35 ppm
Enter immediately wearing surgical masks
options.feedback: INSUFFICIENT! CO requires SCBA for entry into potentially contaminated spaces.

options.text: Wait for fire department clearance

title: Hypothermia Stage III - Severe
pcr_text: Elderly patient found unconscious in snow, core temp 78°F, rigid muscles, no shivering, appears dead. What stage?
correct_error: Stage III hypothermia (severe): <86°F, unconscious, no shivering, appears dead but 'not dead until warm and dead' per environmental protocols.

options.text: Stage III (severe) - unconscious, <86°F, 'not dead until warm and dead'
Stage II (moderate) - still conscious
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Unconscious with rigid muscles = Stage III hypothermia.

options.text: Patient is deceased - no resuscitation
options.feedback: CRITICAL ERROR! Severe hypothermia patients appear dead but can be resuscitated.

title: Electrical Fire - Don't Touch Rule
pcr_text: Electrical panel fire in basement, arcing and sparking, smoke filling house. Should you enter or wait for fire department?
correct_error: Live electrical fire with arcing. DO NOT ENTER - wait for fire department to de-energize per safety protocols.

options.text: Retreat and wait for fire department to secure electrical system
Enter using CO2 extinguisher on electrical fire
options.feedback: CRITICAL ERROR! Live electrical fires require power disconnection first. DO NOT ENTER!

options.text: Approach from upwind side

title: Heat Exhaustion vs Heat Stroke
pcr_text: 45-year-old runner, core temp 101°F, profuse sweating, dizziness, nausea but alert. Heat stroke or exhaustion?
correct_error: Heat exhaustion: <104°F, sweating present, mental status normal per environmental protocols.

options.text: Heat exhaustion - cool, hydrate, rest
Heat stroke - immediate ice water immersion required
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Sweating and normal mental status = heat exhaustion, not stroke.

options.text: Heat cramps - muscle spasms

title: PPE for Suspected COVID-19
pcr_text: Patient with fever, cough, shortness of breath, recent travel history. Suspected COVID-19. What PPE is most critical for respiratory protection?
correct_error: COVID-19 PPE: N95 mask essential for airborne protection per infection control protocols.

options.text: N95 respirator mask - required for airborne COVID-19 protection
Surgical mask - insufficient for COVID-19 protection
options.feedback: INSUFFICIENT! COVID-19 requires N95 for airborne protection.

options.text: Face shield only - misses respiratory protection

title: Drowning - Freshwater Submersion
pcr_text: Child pulled from swimming pool, unconscious, clear frothy sputum, bradycardia. Freshwater or saltwater drowning?
correct_error: Freshwater drowning: hypotonic fluid enters bloodstream causing hemodilution per drowning protocols.

options.text: Freshwater drowning - fluid enters bloodstream causing hemodilution
Saltwater drowning - pulmonary edema
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Pool water is hypotonic - enters bloodstream causing fluid overload.

options.text: Secondary drowning - delayed pulmonary edema

title: Propane Tank Leak - Don't Touch
pcr_text: Barbecue grill propane tank punctured, hissing gas leak, strong odor, ignition source nearby. Should you approach or wait for fire department?
correct_error: Propane gas leak with ignition risk. DO NOT APPROACH - evacuate area and wait for fire department per safety protocols.

options.text: Retreat to safe distance and wait for fire department HazMat team
Approach and attempt to turn off the tank valve
options.feedback: CRITICAL ERROR! Propane leaks are explosion hazards. DO NOT TOUCH!

options.text: Move ignition sources away

title: Frostbite Assessment
pcr_text: 55-year-old with white, hard, cold toes after being lost in snow. What degree of frostbite?
correct_error: Deep frostbite: full-thickness tissue freezing, white/hard/cold, requires hospital thawing per environmental protocols.

options.text: Deep frostbite - full thickness, white/hard/cold, hospital required
Superficial frostbite - red/painful, can rewarm on scene
options.feedback: INCORRECT! White, hard, cold = deep frostbite requiring hospital care.

options.text: Frostnip - mild cold injury, no tissue damage

hazards.action: Do not rewarm deep frostbite on scene

title: PPE for Contact Precautions
pcr_text: Patient with large draining wound infected with MRSA. What is the most important PPE for contact isolation?
correct_error: Contact precautions PPE: gloves and gown mandatory for MRSA protection per infection control protocols.

options.text: Isolation gown - required to prevent clothing contamination
N95 respirator - not required for contact precautions
options.feedback: OVERKILL! MRSA is contact precaution, gown is essential.

options.text: Face shield only - misses clothing protection

title: Scene Size-up - MVC with Fire
pcr_text: Two vehicle collision, one car on fire, patient trapped inside. Should you attempt rescue or wait for fire department?
correct_error: Vehicle fire with trapped patient. DO NOT APPROACH - wait for fire department rescue per safety protocols.

options.text: Retreat and wait for fire department to extinguish and extricate
Approach with fire extinguisher to rescue patient
options.feedback: CRITICAL ERROR! Vehicle fires require fire department intervention. DO NOT ENTER!

options.text: Pull patient out through window

title: Lightning Strike Safety
pcr_text: Group hiking during thunderstorm, one member struck by lightning, unconscious with burns. Should you approach or wait?
correct_error: Lightning storm continues. Wait for 'all clear' before approaching - lightning can strike twice per safety protocols.

options.text: Wait for thunderstorm to completely pass before approaching
Approach immediately using lightning rods for protection
options.feedback: CRITICAL ERROR! Lightning can strike same area twice. Wait for all clear.

options.text: Approach during pauses between lightning

title: PPE for Droplet Precautions
pcr_text: Patient with influenza-like symptoms, fever, cough, runny nose. What PPE is most important for droplet precautions?
correct_error: Droplet precautions PPE: surgical mask essential for respiratory droplet protection per infection control protocols.

options.text: Surgical mask - required for droplet protection
N95 respirator - overkill for droplet precautions
options.feedback: OVERKILL! Surgical mask sufficient for droplet precautions.

options.text: Gown only - misses respiratory protection

title: Hydrogen Sulfide Exposure - Don't Touch
pcr_text: Sewer work site with rotten egg odor, workers unconscious nearby. Suspected H2S exposure. Should you enter or wait for HazMat?
correct_error: Hydrogen sulfide gas exposure. DO NOT ENTER - wait for HazMat with proper monitoring per safety protocols.

options.text: Retreat and wait for HazMat team with gas monitoring equipment
Enter wearing SCBA to rescue workers
options.feedback: OUT OF SCOPE! H2S requires specialized HazMat response. DO NOT ENTER!

options.text: Approach from upwind to assess

title: Cold Water Immersion
pcr_text: 30-year-old fell through ice, 5 minutes in 32°F water, shivering violently, core temp 92°F. What immediate treatment?
correct_error: Cold water immersion: remove wet clothes, warm gradually, monitor for secondary hypothermia per environmental protocols.

options.text: Remove wet clothes, warm with blankets, monitor temperature
Apply heating pads directly to skin
options.feedback: DANGEROUS! Direct heat can cause burns or cardiac arrest in hypothermic patients.

options.text: Give hot fluids to drink

title: PPE for Standard Precautions
pcr_text: Routine patient assessment, no known infectious conditions. What PPE is required when blood exposure is possible?
correct_error: Standard precautions PPE: gloves mandatory when blood/body fluid contact expected per infection control protocols.

options.text: Non-sterile gloves - required for potential blood contact
N95 respirator - not required for standard precautions
options.feedback: OVERKILL! Gloves sufficient for routine blood exposure risk.

options.text: Full isolation gown - not required for standard precautions

title: Confined Space Rescue
pcr_text: Worker unconscious in underground tank, no respiratory equipment available. Should you attempt rescue or wait for specialists?
correct_error: Confined space rescue required. DO NOT ENTER - wait for properly equipped rescue team per safety protocols.

options.text: Retreat and wait for confined space rescue team
Enter tank to perform rescue breathing
options.feedback: CRITICAL ERROR! Confined spaces require specialized training and equipment. DO NOT ENTER!

options.text: Lower rope for self-rescue

title: Altitude Sickness
pcr_text: Hiker at 12,000 feet with headache, nausea, fatigue, mild confusion. Early altitude sickness or something else?
correct_error: Acute mountain sickness: headache, nausea, fatigue at high altitude per environmental protocols.

options.text: Acute mountain sickness - descend immediately, oxygen if available
High altitude cerebral edema - severe confusion
options.feedback: INCORRECT! Mild confusion with headache/nausea = AMS, not HACE.

options.text: Heat exhaustion from exertion
